collection.title: CSRSNT-ZAAI-45-of-64.png
collection.description: always been enamored by casey's work. the depth and intricacies of his pieces from seemingly simple diagonal lines and dashes. takes a special eye to be able to imagine, create and express these aesthetics, casey's eye has always been a favorite of mine.

collection.title: The Starry Night: Not Van Gogh, Not Sorry
collection.description: gans have always been my favorite sub-genre of AI, machine-learning, generative, or 'whatever u want to call it' art. fondness for simpler, more personalized systems. early gan outputs allowed more room for contemplation, emotions, and freedom for the machines to dream. there's a rawness to gans, an aesthetic that feels refreshing and incomparable to other artistic explorations. helena's work with gans is the perfect representation of this.... her style, emotions, story and so much more is expressed through her systems, digitally and physically.

collection.title: Lushtemples — landscape in dark tones
collection.description: say what you want about how skeuomorphic or not digital art should or shouldnt be. zancan crafted something special with his early tezos forestry. an artist that captured an entire chain and is a big reason for helping pushing our niche art nerd scene forward just a little more.

collection.title: Window Still Life 064
collection.description: my partner first recognized john's work from early tumblr days, we became active collectors of his daily windows throughout the early hicetnunc days. fond memories of auto-refreshing tzkt pages, waiting for a mint operations to come through… this one has always been a personal favorite, reminds me of my brother and the countless hours we'd share in front of split-screen tvs.

collection.title: Infinite Garden: 12879 Flowers
collection.description: leander's infinite garden series is a beautiful example of protocol art. becoming the gardener of the digital floral arrangement through online contracts. leander doesn't shy away from hard edges, there's no rush towards realism, but rather a meditative retreat in a field of polygons. cool guy makes cool artwork.

collection.title: Genomes #369
collection.description: one of the most under-appreciated projects in the space. such a lovely blend of aesthetics between two legends, mordvinstev and ciphrds ability to create a procedural system that is reminiscent of the early deepdream textures is *chefs kiss*. can sit and watch this living genome evolve forever.

collection.title: Apparitions #842
collection.description: just a special piece from early days of collecting, surrounded with seemingly nostalgic and fond memories. my partner and i have always said our colors are green and pink, this piece reminds me of her. <3

collection.title: fl(uu)f. luluxxx
collection.description: lulu is an og in the cryptoart space. part of the larger p(jj)tch series, these cat gifs are always a dopamine injection. whatever ascii filter/style transfer system lulu has built is a work of art in itself, a signature style thats unforgettable. also who doesnt love cats?

collection.title: Standard Deck 022
collection.description: elna's illusionary flashing style is such a neat way of conveying motion. all the cards within the standard deck series have a life, a scene, a feeling. i like to imagine the band is playing tezeta by mulatu astatke

writings.title: changing tools
writings.description: The evolution of the syntax labor to intent engineering.
body: we're hitting a strange crossroads as accessible tools evolve. it's the difference between a carpenter who spends all day perfecting a single dovetail joint by hand versus someone using a CNC machine to have 100x the production rate. the end product might look identical, but the mental task model of the person making it is completely different.

for the traditional developer, the manual dexterity of syntax and debugging is where the physical craft lives. but as tools evolve, that skill set starts to feel like a constraint. we're shifting toward intent engineering, where the value isn't in how well you can type, but how clearly you can envision the integration of complex systems. it's a shift from being the worker on the floor to being the one who understands the entire production pipeline.

body.text: if anyone can make software, why do we need developers?

body: ...well, anyone CAN make a sandwich, but we still have thousands of sandwich shops. vibe coders are throwing together a midnight grilled cheese with half-stale bread—it gets the job done (maybe). it still takes an educated figure to understand how to scale this process or refine it.

writings.title: software becoming softer
writings.description: malleability of systems ensures for more fluid workflows
body: in traditional computer science, "spaghetti code" is an ultimate sin because a human eventually has to go back in and fix it or build on top if it. but if an ai can refactor or entirely rewrite ten thousand lines of messy code in a few seconds, does the "cleanliness" even matter anymore? does claude even need to refactor code, or can it just live and work through an entangled mess of sloppy code?

traditional software systems are built to last, but they're rigid. once the concrete sets, you're locked in emotionally and financially. programmers who've spent years building softwares, databases and connected workflows through specific stacks are constrained to their foundational creations. transitioning is a possibility but realistically ill-advised in most scenarios.

this is where the disposability of code takes on a new role. in the physical world, throwing things away is a tragedy of waste. but in code, "permanence" is often just a fancy word for legacy debt…a time sink fallacy that creates bias in intentions and ambitions.

"vibe coding" (or whatever we want to call this ephemeral style) helps move away from the rigid structures. new frameworks, new uis, new themes, new ideas, new everything can be tried, tested and implemented without the risk of having to start from ground up again.

it raises a real question: is it better to spend six months building a "robust" monument thats meant to stand the test of time, or one weekend building a tool that you're totally fine with deleting on monday?

is this a wasteful thought process? an efficient one? how does disposability and waste in the digital world effect us. "soft"ware is meant to be soft…its meant to be malleable, does ai coding make software even softer?

writings.title: machine literacy
writings.description: the gap between owning a device and understanding its potential
body: it is a wild realization that we've taken literal rocks and transformed them into computational super-machines capable of global communication. it becomes an even wilder realization when you consider how early we are in this digital timeline of human history. every year, these devices become more advanced and more intertwined with our existence, yet most of us are locked out of their true potential.

we're limited to experiencing a machine's power through the narrow lens of corporate software, private applications and patented hardwares. you can't tap into a computer's raw mathematical strength without a specific calculator app, and you can't touch its rendering capabilities without a pre-built video game. your phone is packed with lidar, accelerometers and neural engines, but they're basically paperweights unless you're using an app that actually USES these capabilities. it's like owning a high-end laboratory but only being allowed to use the magnifying glass because you dont know how to work with anything else.

but if ai-assisted coding allows the average person to build their own interaction layers to these built in capabilities, the gate collapses. the machine's full capability moves from being a restricted service to a personal utility, making the true power of the "rock" accessible to anyone with an intent and ability to convey it.

it isn't just about "knowing how to code", it's about having the conceptual map to know what is EVEN possible. if you don't realize your phone has a lidar sensor that can map a room in 3d, you'll never think to ask an ai to help you build a tool that measures your furniture. if you don't understand that your gpu is a parallel-processing monster, you'll continue to let it sit idle while you struggle with manual data entry.
the machine stops being a collection of icons and starts being a raw utility. it's about reclaiming the agency to use the laboratory, not just the magnifying glass

website.description: my personal corner of the web
details: a vanilla html/css/js site with tailwind for styling. designed around a single config.json that powers all content across pages.

features a collection gallery for art, a writings section with inline quotes, github integration for projects, and are.na pulls for inspiration. dark mode, scanlines, glass panels - the whole aesthetic.
a project born from the dread of maintaining healthy eating habits. i wanted a simple tool that could take a list of available ingredients in house and recommend dishes i could instantly make.

this expanded into working with recipes i was partially missing ingredients for, to help build shopping lists quick without having to rack your brain on what's missing only to get back from the grocery store realizing you needed three other things.

eventually built in a meal planning section that allows you to catalogue meals you want to eat for the week, generates a shopping list of ingredients you need to fulfill those weekly meals. added specific diet restriction filters to help maintain allergy, calorie or other nutritional needs.
draw layouts and components in a sketch interface, then export to clean html/css. a tool for rapid prototyping without leaving the browser.

latent-sync.title: Better Persistent Memory System
latent-sync.description: transforming claude from a temporary contractor into a long-term partner
details: traditional coding sessions are ephemeral; once the context window fills up or the chat resets, the "intellectual momentum" is lost. latent sync transforms claude from a temporary contractor into a long-term partner by creating a feedback loop between active development (NOW.md) and core project rules (CLAUDE.md).
the machine's "memory" is a living asset you curate, better manage your Claude.md file.
